> You are welcome. I have one question: did you implement this
> successfully for any specific case yet? Your ideas sound very general,
> and I worry that you are thinking too generally too quickly. I
recommend

design

First of all, I forgot of one thing, the "Task": A "Task" is a
publishable method; it can be executed by the user or by some "state
machine". Think in "tasks" like the tasks in Windows explorer side bar.
I have a prototype of a "GUI state machine" working fine using
"SwingFX" , but the code need refactorization.

This is a example of Entity:

@LabelAnnotation("Mock Entity")
@DescriptionAnnotation("A Entity for make a test in Gui EntityPanel")
public class MockEntity {
private String _name = "Luiz Siqueira Neto";
private int _age = 29;
private String _sex = "Male";

@LabelAnnotation("Name")
@DescriptionAnnotation("Entity Name")
@PriorityAnnotation
public String getName() {
return _name;
}

public void setName(String name) {
_name = name;
}

@LabelAnnotation("Age")
@DescriptionAnnotation("Entity Age")
@PriorityAnnotation(5)
public Integer getAge() {
return _age;
}

public void setAge(Integer age) {
this._age = age;
}

@LabelAnnotation("Sex")
@DescriptionAnnotation("This is a sex gender")
@PriorityAnnotation(10)
public String getSex() {
return _sex;
}

public void setSex(String value) {
_sex = value;
}

@LabelAnnotation("Calcule birth day")
@DescriptionAnnotation("Make a calculation to descovery the birth
day")
@PriorityAnnotation(12)
public void calculeBirthDay() {
// implementation ...
}
}

@LabelAnnotation("Mock container")
@DescriptionAnnotation("A container for make a test in EntityPanel")
class MockContainer {

private MockEntity[] _items = null;

@LabelAnnotation("mock entities")
@DescriptionAnnotation("a mock list")
public MockEntity[] getItems() {
return _items;
}

public void setItems(MockEntity[] mockEntityList) {
_items = mockEntityList;
}

public MockEntity getItems(int index) {
return _items[index];
}

public void setItems(int index, MockEntity mockEntity) {
_items[index] = mockEntity;
}

}

The "priority annotation" solve a simple problem; some times a GUI or
a report only can show few properties, in this case the "state machine
" use the priority to determine what need to be show.

For make a test I first create a "MockEntity" and than I create a test
to force the "state machine development". Tell me what you think about
this way of test.

I really appreciate this conversation. :)
